characters: THE CAMERA BEGINS TO TRUCK OUT. IT MOVES AROUND CHARLIE A
AWAY FROM THE HOLY CANDLES REVEALING CHARLIE'S PROFILE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE has been dreaming. The dream frightened him. A TITLE APPEARS on the bottom of the frame: CHARLIE. He get up to look at his face in the mirror. His room is lit by moonlight. It is a small tenement bedroom with a fire- escape outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns to bed and as his head hits the pillow, we hea the RONETTES singing "BE MY BABY."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An 8-mm. projector whirring away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening TITLES appear over 8mm. HOME MOVIES in which CHARLIE is shown along with his friends and family in a celebration...a sense of "one big unending party."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this opening segment WE SEE some of the characters that will later appear in the story: JOHNNY BOY, MICHAEL, TONY, TERESA, CHARLIE'S UNCLE GIOVANNI, and others. They are all Sicilian and are members of the same Italian- American neighborhood in New York City. (WE SENSE, from these HOME MOVIES, that the neighborhood forces its peopl to be strongly tied together in a way of life - Family, Church, Friendship.) These HOME MOVIES were taken during some formal and casual gatherings in which CHARLIE participated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A longhaired "freak" is about to shoot-up. Suddenly the door opens and TONY (ANTHONY DEVENZIANO) comes in. TONY i totally different in appearance and dress from the "freak He is 25, and a part time student studying liberal arts. His father is a very powerful racketeer in a different pa of the city and owns several night club type discotheques and strip houses on the west side of town. One of these i operated by TONY - "TONY'S PLACE." CHARLIE is one of his closest friends. TONY is well dressed, flippant and reckl He is a big drinker, liquor, wine, and even cough medicin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck...hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY rushes over to the "freak", who is too strung out to defend himself, smashes the needle, and slaps him around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in my fuckin' place... get out... get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY pushes him out the door and into the bar area. There are a few people in the bar...mainly neighborhood guys li TONY. A few "freaks" are in the BG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY pushes him out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And keep the fuck out-a-here. I know your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY crosses over to one of the neighborhood guys by the and slaps him in the back of the head knocking off his ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you scumbag...what did I tell you 'bout passin' that shit in my

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey I didn't do nothin'...cut it out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY pushes the BOY out of the bar also. TITLE APPEARS on the bottom of the frame: TONY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The area is totally deserted except for two trucks parked side by side. Two men are tossing boxes from one truck to another and looking around furtively. MICHAEL stands near MICHAEL LONGO is 26 years old. He lives in a different neighborhood but comes from the same type of background a CHARLIE and the others. He runs an illegitimate bar and dabbles in the yearly sale of firecrackers which he smugg in from Maryland. He also deals in contraband cigarettes and runs a small-time "loan shark" business. He has a kna for business but he is otherwise unintelligent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael crosses over to a '58 black Oldsmobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hurry up with that shit will ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL gets in the car. Another MAN is sitting in the ba He is also well dressed. MICHAEL takes a small lens out o his pocket and tosses it to the MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? More shit...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw...that ain't shit...that's a German lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAN looks at it carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good buy...good two shipments of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't use it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why...? That's a telescopic one... it's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, it ain't German...it's Japanese...and second, this ain't no lens...it's like a...a...an adaptor...so you got two shipments of Jap adaptors with no lenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN hands adaptor back to MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Jap adaptor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE APPEARS on bottom of screen: MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deserted warehouse area in lower Manhattan. Prominent i the frame is a brightly painted red white and blue mailbo contrasting with the drab hues of the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY walks down the street toward camera. JOHN CIVELLO (JOHNNY BOY) is 23 years old. He is an only child and lives with his mother, a divorcee. He is clean cut looking, yet slightly radical in dress. He was expelled from high school for vandalism and consequently spent several months in reform school. He is reckless, unambitious, nihilistic, and was classified a psychiatric F. He is first cousin of TERESA RONCHALI who lives next door to CHARLIE. He has adopted TERESA'S family as his ow and spends more time with them than he does with his moth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY is carrying a package wrapped in plain brown paper under his arm, and he is smiling. He drops the package in the mailbox and keeps walking. But he is moving a little faster now and smiling a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the mailbox explodes. Dozens of red, white and blue fragments shower down on the street. The impact of t blast knocks JOHNNY down. TITLE APPEARS on bottom of fram JOHNNY BOY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is up in a moment. The CAMERA TRACKS with him as he starts running. WE SEE that he is grinning - quite literally - like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE CHARLIE full face. Behind him is a Confessional Booth. The church is very old, quiet, and dark. The CAMER ZOOMS OUT to reveal rows of Holy Candles lit in the foreground. CHARLIE suddenly begins to speak softly and confidentially to an unseen entity that is OFF SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A...As you know, I've just come out of Confession. And as a penance they gave me ten 'Hail Marys' and ten 'Our Fathers'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now, between you and me... You know how I feel about such things... 'Hail Marys'...'Our Fathers'...No imagination...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA HAS NOW TRUCKED BEHIND CHARLIE AND WE SEE over his head he has been addressing a life sized statue of th crucified body of Christ, eyes closed reclining in his sepluchure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If I'm going to do penance at all, I'll do it the way I think it would be done...by me, that is...according to my own trespasses. You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This conversation of Confession will occur from time to t in other parts of the story as CHARLIE will periodically very casually to justify his thoughts and actions to his "God." The images accompanying these monologues are to be free association almost documentary in nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The club is dark and noisy and smokey when CHARLIE enters He greets TONY who is sitting on a bar-stool. TONY direct CHARLIE to a corner of the club where the rest of the gro is now getting boisterously drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE joins in, immediately taking on the mood of the g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the club is filled with many different types customers: teenagers, adults pretending to be teenagers, sailors, male and female gays, and "the boys from the neighborhood." The music is loud and the lights are flash but the strippers have not yet appeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY is at the bar. He is approached by GEORGE one of the bouncers. He seems upset about the noise that CHARLIE and his friends are creating. TONY doesn't take GEORGE very seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ten o'clock and they're like this. And they're just starting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile...What are you smiling at? This is a business night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George...did I ever tell you the story about the three chickens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE's zany behavior as frenetically as it occurs. The is no particular logical sequence except that events are suited to the rythmic pattern of the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. CHARLIE and his friends dance and sing along with the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2. CHARLIE picks up a billiard stick. He attempts to hit filled shot glass towards TONY at the other end of the bar. He fails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3. CHARLIE tries to pull a tablecloth off of a stranger's table without moving the glasses or bottles. This also fails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4. A punch is thrown at someone. A lit cigarette in the puncher's fist creates a swift arc of light in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5. The Strippers finally appear on stage. CHARLIE becomes obsessed with the Negro stripper DIANE. He shouts to her, tosses things, and calls her names. She tries, half amusedly to ignore him but she can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 6. TONY drinks from a bottle of Southern Comfort, and as chaser swigs down Aqua Velva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE sitting at an empty table watching DIANE, the stripper, perform again. He stares glassy-eyed and then begins to speak softly, continuing his Confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know...she's really good-looking... really good-looking. I've gotta say that again. She's really good- looking...but she's black... You can see that real plain. (as an afterthought) When you get down to it though... there's not much of a difference, is there? (He waits for an answer) Well...is there? (He smiles and begins chewing on an ice cube from his half

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly MICHAEL appears and sits down at CHARLIE's table He hands CHARLIE two cartons of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh great...hey - Winstons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For these prices don't be particular. That's all they had - but next week we'll see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE gives him the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, ok...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sell 'em if you can't smoke them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...I'll be ok for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seen Johnny Boy tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he supposed to be here tonight...I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look...I don't know. What am I supposed to be, his keeper or something? Yeah, he's supposed to be here but who knows what goes on in his head. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to know Charlie, it looks like your little friend is trying to duck me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Charlie, don't you think you should be interested in Johnny's payments to me? I think you should be, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, nobody's out to screw you, I guarrantee that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that Charlie but look at my side. You undersigned the loans. You vouched for him. What happens if this kid don't pay me? I gotta collect from you? I don't want to do that. I made a deal with him not you, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. You're right. Look, I'm not gonna wind up paying his debts. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that. That's what I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, believe me. You know the kid's a little crazy sometimes. I vouched for him and he'll come through. I promise. I'll talk to him and straighten him out. Don't worry, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY enters the night club with two friends. He has been drinking. JOHNNY BOY'S face shows fresh cuts and bruises. His friends approach the hat check girl and give her their coats. JOHNNY BOY approaches her giving her his pants instead. His friends laugh hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is now alone at the end of the bar. JOHNNY BOY no completely dressed enters the bar area. CHARLIE watches JOHNNY BOY approaching and continues his Confession. JOHN BOY greets people as he passes them, and as CHARLIE speak he appears to be moving in slow motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? 'If a man have a hundred sheep, and one of them stray, will he not leave the ninety-nine in the mountains, and go in search of the one that has strayed? And if he happen to find it, amen I say to you, he rejoices over it more than over the ninety- nine that did not go astray. Even so, it is not the will of your Father in Heaven that a single one of these little ones should perish.'... Ok that's very nce but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY is now behind the bar near CHARLIE. JOHNNY BOY has reached them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinks for everybody Tony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giovanino! Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and a double for you and Charlie here. (quietly to TONY) And put it on my tab, willya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one, the big tab or the little tab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it on the little tab so that it balances with the big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so things'll be even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY grimace. MICHAEL appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about me? I don't get a drink John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! A double for Michael, Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY interrupts MICHAEL who is about to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're going to say but don't say it. These drinks are all on the tab. I'm gonna see you this Tuesday payday, I promise. I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drinks arrive. They all smile and salute each other with their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The queen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The queen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY are sitting alone at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refering to JOHNNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you Flash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, I swear on my mother, you're not going to believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but let's hear it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God Charlie, it's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY is walking along the street. It is rush hour a the traffic is heavy. A shiny, late model car stops paral to JOHNNY BOY. The young boy (SAL) signals him by blowing the horn. (Note that in the FLASHBACK, JOHNNY BOY'S face not bruised.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Johnny, where're you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sal!... fourteen street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is some boat. Your father's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...just had it delivered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... you got stereo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JOHNNY BOY admires the gadgets in the car he notices t SAL is becoming very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a speaker back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to look for the speaker and sees a police car no far behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...there's a funny lookin' cab behind us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'sa matter...forget your registration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no. Nooo...it's just that I...I...uh... this ain't my car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's your father's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it's heisted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (announcing it loudly) This is a heisted car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAL smiles sheepishly. JOHNNY BOY panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police switch on their flashing red light and try to closer to them but the traffic is too heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAL manages to turn the next corner at about twenty miles per hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY frightened now, underestimates the speed of th car and quickly opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY tumbles from the car only to smack into a lamp post. He has seriously banged his head and blood is runni down his face. But because of the near proximity of the police car he is desperately trying to maintain an air of dignity as he calmly tries to walk down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY has now joined the group sitting at the table... CHARLIE and TONY nod in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the truth, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, forget it. Tony, you got anything we can put on his face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I got something to show you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They push their way through the crowd and enter a narrow dimly lit hallway on both sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy and girl are necking on a make-shift couch in the darkened room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy, I tell you there's something in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh come on baby...willya'...cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the light is turned on. TONY, CHARLIE, and JOHNN BOY enter the room. The GIRL is startled and jumps up. JIMMY appears bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us Jimmy, we'll only be a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'alright Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL and JIMMY sit self-consciously as TONY goes to t medicine cabinet, takes out a few items and gives them to CHARLIE. TONY then crosses to the other side of the room where he removes the blanket which has been covering a la cage. He reveals a live, young beautiful PANTHER stalking to and fro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you there was something in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone else except TONY, is backed up against the wall, frightened. The BOYS laugh nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep quiet about this. I don't have any license for him yet. I've only had him a couple of days. Nobody can feed him except me. I'm the only one he trusts. Watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go to any trouble. We believe you... We believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY begins to open the cage. The BOYS are now standing o top of the nearest pieces of furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really wanted to get a little tiger Charlie, y'know...a little William Blake and all that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY ignores CHARLIE's warning as he crouches and allows animal to wander onto his lap where upon he strokes the panther gently murmuring to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS watch in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Italian song "Malafemina" (a tango-like rythmn) is he coming from the juke-box. It is near closing time and the are only a few customers left in the club, including MICH and two gays, BENTON and SAMMY, who is getting very drunk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is at the corner table with TONY and JOHNNY BOY. CHARLIE is washing JOHNNY BOY'S face with cold water from basin. Some of JOHNNY'S blood has mingled with the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised at you Tone. I mean you've had the place for over a year now. Nothing different...same old place...ordinary...flat...no imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY ignores CHARLIE's half-joking, drunken remarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For instance, the difference between me and you is this...you take that panther back there. I'd put him right up here above the bar...nice cage, you know? Nothing ordinary in my place. What good is it? You get robot customers. They come in, drink beer, go to the bathroom, and go home. No sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the BOYS more casual acquaintances is lying on the bar, drunk. He begins to sing along with the Italian music - but very badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A question please...'Is this what you call living?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Take a little tip from Mack the Knife...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, break down and open another bottle willya'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well dressed young boy enters the club. GEORGE, the bouncer, approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just waiting for Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY walks over to a bar stool and sits down. Nobody acknowledges his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the DRUNK on the bar stops singing and sits up, dazed. His sudden silence causes CHARLIE and the others t look up at him. The DRUNK stares ahead for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I gotta go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVERYONE laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, go ahead, whaddaya want? Someone to hold it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More laughter. Even the BOY at the bar laughs. The DRUNK rises, still smiling and stumbles off to the mens room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Bopper - "Chantilly Lace" in playing on the soundtrack. CHARLIE is playing with a deck of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing previous conversation) This place is dead. If I had a place...every night...lively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY is sipping his drink and ignoring the conversa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I wouldn't call it TONY'S PLACE or CHARLIE'S PLACE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd call it something like SEASON OF THE WITCH... get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are with out a doubt the biggest, most pretentious bullshit thrower I know. Like to see what kind of business you'd do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's talking. Pretentious bullshit. Who's the guy with William Blake and the tigers, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you guys shut up with the witches and tigers. Tony, you gonna close the place, we get out of here, get something to eat, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll close up as soon as everybody leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget what's-his-name there in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVERYONE laughs. JIMMY is drawing on a table top. CHARLIE wanders over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna see your picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE leans over. OVERHEAD VIEW shows large crude swast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waddaya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite...but keep trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE picks up the cards again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a game after we close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Tony, waddaya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody wanna have a game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people in the bar do not respond. CHARLIE shrugs. The BOY casually leaves the bar and walks to the men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY slowly swings the door open and stares at the DRU leaning over the urinal, half asleep. He takes out his pistol and calmly shoots the DRUNK three times in the bac To the BOY's surprise the DRUNK does not immediately fall dead. Instead, he turns and grabs the BOY by the throat. They struggle in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Italian music is still playing. Everyone in the bar h frozen in position as they watch the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his astonishment CHARLIE allows the cards to fall from his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The YOUNG BOY breaks away from the DRUNK and runs towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRUNK, running only on sheet determination, stumbles along after the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people in the bar, including CHARLIE, dash behind tab and jump behind the bar for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY reaches the exit and fires at the DRUNK from the of the stairs. The DRUNK still follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET - NIGHT BLACK & WHITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY runs down the street and disappears into the dark The DRUNK staggers out into hte cobblestone street. His mind is gone, it is now just a physical matter of the bod being stopped by the presence of a stationary object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers straight across the street at tremendous spee smashing directly into a parked car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. TONY'S PLACE - BACK ENTRANCE - NIGHT BLACK & WHI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone (including the two GAYS at the bar) is running o the back way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't run...don't run. Everyone split up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET - NIGHT BLACK & WHITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL and JIMMY turn the corner and calmly walk to his parked car. As they get into the car CHARLIE and JOHNNY B turn the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, give us a lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they are getting into the car the two GAYS turn the corner. One of them, SAMMY, is very drunk and is crying hysterically. His companion BENTON is trying to calm him down when he notices MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael...wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is obvious that MICHAEL does not want to take them but is also afraid of attracting any attention so he quickly ushers them into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in, get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. MICHAEL'S CAR - NIGHT BLACK & WHITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY are in the back seat. SAMMY crawls over CHARLIE into the back seat making apologies. BENTON forced into the front seat with MICHAEL and JIMMY. They drive off, with SAMMY crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ...what's this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy get control of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you're gettin' it all over my tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I slap him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly in control) You wouldn't dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry guys...It's just that he was terribly frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep him quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends of yours Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing the hostility) Oh...ah...I'm Benton and this is Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get over the way he just kept going at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have been all the liquor in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns to English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where should I drop you Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting the conversation) Yes Charlie, your place or mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away from the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Benton...look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMMY leans over JOHNNY and CHARLIE to see out the window He begins to shout at a young boy on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi beautiful!!! I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY hide their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...are you kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy, get in here this minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't...I won't! They're all beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll suck them all...I'll suck them all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY groan. They are still hiding their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgraceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok...that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the car over to the nearest corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You getting out too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks, it's ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET - NIGHT BLACK & WHITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY get out of the car first so that b the time BENTON and SAMMY are out they are already on the way down the street. MICHAEL drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going our way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JOHNNY BOY) Don't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BENTON guides SAMMY the opposite way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY are walking down the street on the way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I should go home looking like this. You think I could stay at your place tonight? Your mother's not there is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE lives in a typical lower east side tenement apart Each room is painted a different pastel color. It is furnished in miscellaneous styles and from the pictures o the wall and various knick-knacks around the rooms it is evident that this is a family apartment rather than a bachelors pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is helping his mother pack a suitcase. Through ou the scene he is addressing her but she is never seen on CAMERA. The CAMERA PANS following his movements and CHARL directs his conversation always towards but above and bey it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'll be ok...it's the best thing. You're not going to be able to take care of Grandma out here and still get to work, you know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes the place will be here, I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah don't worry about me, I'll take care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves into the bedroom taking more items out of the drawers. The room is ver small. The paint if peeling. Over the double bed there is a large crucifix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, look, just don't worry...ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and JOHNNY BOY are lying on CHARLIE'S MOTHER'S be in their underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better make a move kid. He thinks you're trying to screw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't bother me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, big man...get yourself in more trouble. You make a fool out of him, you're doing the same to me. I signed for you don't forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't handle shit. You just better come through with some kind of payment on Tuesday...anything. Understand? Hold onto your pay- check this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be any this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sick or what? You forget what we had to do to get you on the trucks, stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like loading crates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to like it. What gets me is your attitude. Listen... tomorrow you show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your attitude...Where's your job...eh? You talk and talk and I go to work...what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I don't do... I don't owe anybody 2,000 clams plus interest, stupid. Show up or I break both your arms, we understand each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, ok...take it easy. I'll show. Tuesday I'll give Michael something. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't promise...just deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, now that that's over with...what are you gonna make me for breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't wait until Tuesday. I'll break your arms right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising from bed) Listen...I'm a guest here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE reaches out to grab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK...ok...I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY is raiding the icebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...you got nothing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the other room) I could have told you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get some food from my aunt's. I'll get in through the fire escape. She's always got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY leaves the kitchen and walks towards the bedro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. You'll scare Teresa if you try to sneak in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY is now by the window looking out at the fire escape mischieviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...you're right. Maybe she'll have a seizure and we can watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs. CHARLIE hits JOHNNY BOY on the back of the hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not funny. You gonna be a jerk-off all your life. Grow up. You want something to eat from your aunt's house you go knock on her door, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry anymore. I'm going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHNNY BOY gets into bed. CHARLIE goes into the kitchen t get a glass of milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE takes a glass of milk from the icebox. He listens to the sounds of the neighborhood waking up and getting ready to go to work. He leaves the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE returns to the bedroom. JOHNNY BOY appears to be asleep. CHARLIE goes to the window and peers through the blinds. He sees in the window across the fire escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF DISSOLVES. TERESA is going through the variou stages of getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERESA RONCHALI is 30 years, well built, attractive and intelligent. She is well read and quiet. The salary she makes as a secretary in a book publishing firm practicall supports her family. She has epilepsy which has prevented her (in her own mind) from entering into any serious relationships with men. She has however, been having an affair with CHARLIE for the past year. It is a well kept secret from both families because the families regard eac other as blood relations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is startled by JOHNNY BOY who is now awake and ha begun to dial the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pretending to be angry) Hello...fifth precinct? Yeah...I want to report a disturbance. Yeah this man and woman next door are disturbing the peace. They're keeping me awake all night now. What the hell is this. What? Well... yelling, fighting, throwing things. Uh-huh. If they don't kill each other soon I'm goin' over there and do the job myself. Yes - the address is 270 Mott street. I think it's apartment 2-r. Yeah, right... thanks. Look, I demand immediate action. Never mind my name I don't like getting involved in things like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up roughly and returns to his position in bed. CHARLIE shakes his head with an exasperated smile as if t was a common occurance. CHARLIE turns back to look at TERESA but she is no longer in her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is dreaming this sequence. He and TERESA are both nude. She is lying face down on the bed. He approached an ejaculates prematurely - However, he doesn't ejaculate sperm - instead blood. They are shocked. The blood is on the bed, her legs, back, and his hands. Charlie cries out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and TERESA are in the hotel room making love. The sounds of traffic can be heard from the street below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to eat something before I go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, we'll go for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE checks his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...with the hotel that's ten... fifteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him a few bills. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the money into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...it's not that...I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching his face) It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if things go the way I hope they'll go, this money business will take care of itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God willing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An apartment uptown? Downtown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, who knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows anything, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERESA is putting on her stockings. A few minutes have passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See if you can get your hands on some pamphlets on laws or by laws...or proprietorship...you know...at your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything specific?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know...like restaurants, night clubs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a quick kiss on the tip of her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... Hey, did you hear any more about what happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIST, you should have seen it. Unbelievable. The kid would turn around and fire and he would just keep coming at him like Rasputin. That kid was scared. Not half as much as we were though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any sense. He wouldn't shoot him just because he insulted a racket guy...not unless it was personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed the point. The kid's a climber...not very bright...but if you get down to his level to look at it his way; he kills a guy who insulted a big man - he gets a reputation. He thinks he's in good standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not sick...just stupid. Speaking of stupid, your cousin last night was feeling so good he decided to break into your mother's house...to get some food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERESA laughs at this story but her mood changes suddenly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure he doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE enters the bathroom to clean-up. He stares at his image in the mirror for a moment, then makes a face. He checks the whiteness of his teeth, pulls back his hair, a checks his complexion. The mirror image begins to speak. The CAMERA PANS BACK to CHARLIE'S FACE. His mouth is not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me like that, I can see this is not going to get us anywhere. She's a good kid, what am I supposed to do. In a way I'm doing her a favor...no??? How many guys you know feel this way about an epileptic? Don't get me wrong, I'm no saint...not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The image of CHARLIE in the bathroom intercuts with still from Catholic School text books - vulgar color illustrati of parables - emphasis on Christ expelling the devils fro the posessed women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not like the Pharisee who said "Oh God I thank thee that I am not like the rest of them."...no...I like to think of myself as the Publican...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strikes his breast penitently as he delivers the next

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...'Oh God be merciful to me the sinner!' I'm not taking advantage of her. I swear to you that if she meets someone she'd like to marry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to CHARLIE in sync.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'll cut out. "If Thy eye is an occasion of sin to thee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stills of girls, sexy pornographic nude magazine spreads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...pluck it out and cast it from thee." "Woe to the man through whom scandal does come." I'm sure you'd agree this is no time to get tied down. Like the priesthood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Textbook illustration of vocations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...they don't get tied down do they? "Have I not a right to do what I chose? Even so the last shall be first and the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE in sync.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...first last. For many are called but few are chosen."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is sitting in a quiet corner of the restaurant. This restaurant was considered an above average business with quality and prices to match when it was first opened three years ago. The quality has diminished but the price remain the same. As a result the place is dying. CHARLIE is scrutinizing the restaurant from his corner. He picks a water goblet and critically examines the water spots on He calls a waitress to show her the dirt on the glass. Sh apologizes, cleans it with her apron, and places it back the table. He takes a menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chubby, middle-aged man, OSCAR, approaches the table. H is half owner of the decaying restaurant. He is in his shirt sleeves which, along with the side of his face, are smeared with grease and dirt. He is tired and disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight Jewish accent) Hey...you're here. They told me you're here...and you're here. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, how's everything going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OSCAR sits down next to CHARLIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't ask...do you have any idea what I've been doing all morning...eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the basement fixing the pipes. Would you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What pipes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What pipes...the ones from last year...those pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE shakes his head in sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Charlie, you're a good boy. Will you just tell your uncle that I have nothing. There is nothing to give him. No envelopes with cash inside, no checks, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make this week's payment and if this keeps up not next week's either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not next week's either...listen...you tell that to Giovanni, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I should wrap up this place in a ribbon and hand it to him, you know that. I don't need this aggravation. I'm getting old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd rather have the loan payed, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Uncle's a good man...I won't stick him. Either he gets the money or the place and right now he's getting the place. And tell me why should I care? I got a partner who's a bum, who doesn't help out...who disappears and leaves me with all the problems. I should go back to Florida...I don't need this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, where's Groppi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should know? His wife don't even know. Probably off with one of his little girls...I don't know. I tell you, if he don't give a damn, then I don't give a damn...Why should I kill myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My uncle figured that this week was bad...but about next week...I dunno. Maybe you should speak to him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is walking down the street on the lower east side A noisy religious street festival is being held on the bl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE enters a small Italian cafe and nods greetings to some of the people as he makes his way to the back of the room. This cafe is a strange hybred of coffee house, cand store, luncheonette, and meeting place for CHARLIE'S uncl GIOVANNI and his associates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIOVANNI De STEFANO is sixty. He is well respected and powerful both in and out of the neighborhood. He became a head figure not by being introduced formally as was the custom, but rather by fighting and killing his way into t organization. GIOVANNI is well dressed but not a stereoty of an old Mafioso, rather a kindly and intelligent old ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIOVANNI converses intermittently in Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man is putting new records into the jukebox which is in the corner of the room in the luncheonette area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to repair man) Is my uncle back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE points in the direction of a doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I think he's busy now. Hey Charlie play 463 today - for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE walks through the luncheonette area, past the din room where his uncle is in conference, to the bathroom at the very back of the cafe. MARIO is seated with his uncle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIO is forty five years old. He is GIOVANNI'S closest associate, brought into the organization in the tradition manner, making his early reputation through hits (murders He is not very intelligent but has an undying loyalty to GIOVANNI, and is very fond of CHARLIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIO and GIOVANNI are seated with a very old man. They a deep in their private conversation. CHARLIE passes by unnoticed and walks into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE begins to wash his hands but changes his mind. He shuts off the faucet in order to eavesdrop on the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIOVANNI and MARIO are calmly sipping their coffee as the listen to the old man's nervous talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm telling you is that he did it for Mario's honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't understand. I knew the kid. He was drunk. He made of fool of himself...not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giovanni - an insult to Mario is an insult to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Italian with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy only did what was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son only did what was stupid. We have enough down here without something like that. And what for? ...Nothing...no reason. Protect him? Why? I didn't tell him to do anything for me. He's going to Miami? Good...keep him in Miami for six months...a year...a good long time. After everything's forgotten then I see what I can do for him. Right now...keep him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is seated at a table. The waitress, MARIE, approaches and gives him his cup of coffee... The followi scene is reminiscent of a TELEVISION COMMERCIAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie, are there Columbian coffee beans in this coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second. Let me taste it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses to sip the coffee, then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'd say there are some Columbian coffee beans in this coffee, but only about 39%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIE is disinterested. CHARLIE continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see. You probably don't notice this Marie, but Colombian coffee beans are rich coffee beans. Bursting with that good, deep coffee flavor. Picked when they are ripe to the point of perfection. The beans of course, are protected by the tall South American Guama trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIE chews her gum for a moment and leaves the table. CHARLIE'S monologue continues and gradually he falls back into his CONFESSION. As he talks, the CAMERA PICKS UP DETAILS of the cafe and the people in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the bean pickers come down and pick each bean by hand. Bean by bean, all heavy with flavor. And they load them into boxes, one box at a time, box by box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From time to time CHARLIE is casually glancing at MARIE w is busy with her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK & WHITE & COLOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The images now move out of the cafe and the CAMERA REVEAL aspects of the neighborhood - LIVE ACTION and STILLS: stores, people, streets, buildings, in short; a concise vision of the neighborhood. All this is intercut with CHARLIE mentally stripping MARIE's clothes off with his e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like, looking at my uncle back there. One way is the obvious; ...man outside the law. On the other hand, instead of a breakdown of order there is a creation of order and instead of the breakdown of law, there is the creation of law...In this society which needs new law because 'What's a crowbar compared to a share of stock. What's the robbing of a bank compared to the founding of one and what's the murder of a man to the gainful employment of that man.' 'Do not think that I have come to destroy the Law or the Prophets. I have not come to destroy but to fulfill.' ...Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The image culminate in aerial shots of downtown New York City. (STOCK FOOTAGE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE now sees MARIE totally naked as she serves the customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIOVANNI and CHARLIE are standing and talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle, how are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Did you have a good time last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About that shooting last night...I was there and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you weren't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is struck silent for a moment. He listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right uncle. I must have gotten it confused with something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and GIOVANNI are now sitting at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Oscar...I think he put on this act...about the restaurant being in bad shape and all that. He can't make the payments...I don't know what to make of it. He says Groppi's run off with a girl. I could help if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...his business is bad. But I'll decide what to do and you...and you just keep out of anything that might...might...er draw attention to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...I understand...I'll be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and TERESA are sitting on the beach which is fair deserted. There are rented cottages behind them. TERESA has a book and some papers from which she is supposed to write a term paper for CHARLIE'S English class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon Charlie...one more day. I'll call in sick for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...we can come back in a couple of weeks. Besides, if we're both gone for three days it wouldn't look right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE picks up a copy of Henry James' Portrait of a Lad and tries to read it. He tosses it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A paper on that one too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...but don't worry about that now. The Hemmingway one is first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nothing. I'm almost finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your time. I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't. You've been very preoccupied lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the word...preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE turns towards TERESA and tries to kiss her. She playfully turns away. But CHARLIE quickly gets bored with that and doesn't pursue her. She is confused by his actio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and TERESA already farther up the beach, walking. They notice a very beautiful house with limousines parked front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that...know who lives there? The name George Earhardt mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...He lives there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Of course he lives there. Would I point it out to you if he didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is seen from a great distance. CHARLIE'S VIEWPO There is great activity...all with a very businesslike ai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That W.A.S.P. bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're intolerable today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE and TERESA are coming in, putting down the books papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it here...alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She caresses CHARLIE. He is still preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to take that apartment uptown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhuh...probably a good idea. Why don't you do it this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why...with my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you can't blame them in a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away from him) I can take care of myself. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE'S father is the patient in the bed. The visitors surrounding the bed are CHARLIE'S mother, TERESA, and TERESA'S mother. The CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSER AS WE HEAR th sounds of mechanical voices coming from the T.V. sets in lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERESA'S mother leans over and whispers into CHARLIE'S father's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turridu...that's your boy Charles. Don't you know him. Isn't that Charles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer. CHARLIE is embarrassed. TERESA'S MOTHER asks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Che Guevara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE doesn't know how to react. TERESA'S MOTHER looks with a half smile in disbelief. The other Visitors give o a small ripple of nervous laughter, repeating it...in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE looks about nervously. Through the door of the hospital room can be seen several of the older patients gathered around a T.V. in the hallway. They are watching the races, the announcer's voice is blaring almost incomprehensibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERESA and CHARLIE make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is getting dressed. TERESA is wrapped warmly in t sheets - still in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He must have heard the name from those T.V.'s in the hall that were blaring all the time. I remember GUEVARA was in town at the time. Must've heard it from there I guess...but that's funny, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummmmmmmmmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of all people. Now say the truth. Do I look like Che Guevara. C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh. He crosses to TERESA and they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been running round too much. Bet you've been forgetting your medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The green capsules in the top drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE gets her the pills and heads out of the cottage f a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is walking along the roadway and looking at the different cottages. He is carrying a notebook to which he periodically refers. He stops in front of a luxurious cottage and checks the address on the signpost with the o in his notebook beside which is listed the name GROPPI. H remains standing at a safe distance from the cottage star at it. It looks deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE walks directly to the front door of the cottage a rings the bell confidently. The door is opened immediatel which startles him. From inside the house we see GROPPI'S back as he holds the door open. He is in a satin robe. We can see CHARLIE'S startled face through the partially ope door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment a nude girl, her back to the CAMERA appear in the FOREGROUND. This startles CHARLIE even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?.......well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I'm selling encyclopedias...er a magazines...newspapers...I'm conducting a survey...I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want no fuckin' books!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROPPI slams the door in CHARLIE'S face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is still standing in front of the cottage. Sudden a little boy of about nine appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody here mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE turns in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this Jack Groppi's place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But he ain't here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY leads him towards a heavily overgrown treed area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much farther?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE repeats this question periodically as he follows BOY. Finally CHARLIE finds himself alone in the middle of dense forest with the BOY nowhere in sight. He calls out but there is no answer. He realizes he's been had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, don't get excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is trying to find his way out of the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The stone which the builders' reject will become the cornerstone'...I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud brass band is playing "Oh Johnny, Oh Johnny, How Y Can Love" inside the cafe. They are part of a religious festival and GIOVANNI has invited them in for drinks. In return they are playing for him. GIOVANNI has been drinki The song ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play it again!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs and joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more time...play it again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band begins the song for the second time. CHARLIE enters the cafe and goes directly to his uncle who embrac him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: over the music) Take a drink!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE sits next to his uncle and looks around at the cr in the cafe which is now singing along with the band. GIOVANNI is smiling broadly. Loud applause follow the end of the song and the band tries clumsily to make its way through the crowd and out of the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...around...why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard what happened to GROPPI, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE gets very nervous at the mention of GROPPI'S name

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who me? ...No, I don't know, not me...all I know is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts CHARLIE off with a gesture of his forefinger) Our friend, Groppi, went to his mother's house. And when he was there...at night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old woman is sitting in front of the television watchi JOHNNY CARSON'S TONIGHT SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continues in voice over) ...he walks into his mother's room where she's watching television...and he says to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROPPI has entered the room with his back to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that he's sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROPPI leaves the frame. The old woman looks up from the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE GROPPI walking towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over continued) ...he goes in the next room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROPPI TURNS ON the bathroom light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over continued) ...he takes a gun and puts it in his mouth and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GROPPI stands with the gun in his hand. He lifts it to hi head. He puts the barrel into his mouth. He pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an Italian hand gesture) ...so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is visibly shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that, eh? He was always a little crazy, y'know... Groppi... a little crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE looks up to see MICHAEL, standing at the entrance the cafe. He waves to CHARLIE in a friendly manner. CHARL waves back and GIOVANNI looks up, squinting to see who it MICHAEL does not approach the table. In respect to GIOVAN he signals to CHARLIE that he would like to see him outsi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now...in a few minutes...ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is surprised at being spoken to in such a curt manner, especially in GIOVANNI'S presence because he feel he has lost status. CHARLIE and GIOVANNI continue their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him all the breaks I can give.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Michael, look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevamind 'look'...This punk bastard...I call him at work...I say 'Johnny Boy there?'...He doesn't even show up for work anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look...I've talked to him and I've talked to him...what more can I do...? Tonight at the party all three of us get together and we knock some sense into his head...ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right...but understand, I don't like being taken advantage of. I mean you're in there talking with your uncle and all...This is embarassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll settle it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two YOUNG BOYS about 15 years old walk up to CHARLIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you sell firecrackers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Firecrackers! No...no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where we can get some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, see that guy over there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...him. He's got the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS go over to MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - fella...you sell firecrackers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh! Quiet. (He looks around) Y'know that's illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well the guy over there said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, never mind. You gotta be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went down to Chinatown but they don't have any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, keep away from those Chinx. They don't have shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we got $40, and we wanna buy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Quiet! For $40 I could give you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know if we want to buy all $40 worth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! You want good stuff, or you want shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we want good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my stuff comes from Maryland... you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means it's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got sparklers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cherry bombs...ash cans...and rockets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok. For another $5.00 a special on the packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, all we got is $40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok. Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL goes to TONY, who has been standing in front of t cafe with a group of boys. They talk for a minute, and go back to the waiting boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the boys) C'mon. Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them get into TONY'S car. They drive to CHINATOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, you guys get out, and wait here for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get the stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we come with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody sees where I get the stuff. That's good business. I'll be back in thirty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey hold it! Gimmie the cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...can we give you a check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A check? What the...hey, where you kids from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riverdale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe they do that in Riverdale, but down here we take cash. Now, you got it or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They give him the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok. Now wait here...and keep your mouths shut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. $20. Here, $5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you spare it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up at TONY'S PLACE. TONY yells to CHARLIE, who is standing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Charlie. Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a'matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Just stiffed those kids. Don't want'em comin' back and findin' you...start asking you questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go to the movies...on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok guys...have a heart. This is my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK & WHITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are paying for their tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DONOVAN'S REEF is showing. We see a brief scene from the film which has JOHN WAYNE fighting LEE MARVIN in a big ba room brawl.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys smile and watch.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. CHINATOWN - NIGHT BLACK & WHITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two boys from Riverdale are still watching on the corner, in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is at home shaving.
CHARLIE (CONFESSION)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know damn well what's going to happen tonight. I'll probably get drunk at that party...it isn't every day you send one of your best friends off to war for God and country... gotta have a party. I mean, he's a nice kid.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE is gluing on a fake beard.  CHARLIE (VOICE OVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what You think of him but that's between You and him anyway...I can't help feeling sorry for him though. Has a talent but doesn't use it...His brain. An 'Unprofitable servant who shall be cast forth into the darkness outside, where there will be...  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Television image of old women mourning their dead in Indi The images are slow motion. The news continues with more trivial news images...(Washington investigations, demonstrations, etc.)  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued voice over) ...the weeping and the gnashing of teeth'...or something like that. My talent's my brain too but I use my talent...I'm not saying that I'm a genius...You'll probably be the first one to agree on that, but I can tell the difference between the intelligent and the stupid. Take the army for example...  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE grabbing a white robe off his bed. We don't see h face.  CHARLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued voice over) That's there and I'm here and that's the way it's going to stay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY enters the bathroom, turns on the light and locks th door. Party noises can be heard in the background TONY is wearing an overcoat and is dressed as a World War I "doug boy". Atop his head is a mask, the features of which can' be seen. He opens the coat to reveal twenty packets of re Jello. He turns on the hot water in the bathtub and slowl begins to empty each packet of Jello into the tub of stea water.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIVING ROOM & KITCHENETTE - PARTY - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the characters that were at the club the other ni are present at the party. Many of them are dressed in sem masquerade outfits. Some are wearing soldiers' uniforms. One wears a sheet made up to be a Roman Toga. The girls a in costumes also. All of the costumes are makeshift. MICHAEL is made up as Dracula, sporting a large cape, sem tuxedo-type suit, and a drop of blood on the corner of hi mouth. His hair is slicked back to give him a "Bela Lugos look. He is showing a picture of a girl to one of the boy proudly proclaiming that she is his latest conquest. TONY comes out of the bathroom and passes by. He takes the pho from MICHAEL. Group attention focuses on TONY now. He stares at the picture, holds it away from him, then close to his face, then sideways and finally upside-down.  TERESA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure! I know her Michael...In fact, I saw her a few days ago under a bridge in Jersey, making out with a nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL grimaces in shock. He spits.  MICHAEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?...a nigger...Uh!...and I kissed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes his lips with his cape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guest of honor, the young soldier is very drunk. He i attempting to open his going away presents, one of which turns out to be a carefully folded American flag.
